content:
✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Simple and fast clash of code, ok for me :)

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: fun, easy to solve

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Good Clash. Fun to solve.

Nice @Lukam90!

Your contribution has been uploaded twice. Please remove one of them. The other link is:
https://www.codingame.com/contribute/view/8489294c3588f4447b8d72c8a62738f1c67cd

Binary output issue
* As per contribution guidelines, binary output issue should be avoided in clashes. In your clash, there are only two possible answers: "valid" and "invalid". Hence, there's a binary output issue. Please revise the output requirement to fix this issue.

Output
* Please format "valid" and "invalid" as {{constants}} and remove the quotation marks.

Thanks.

Thanks to notice me that I had my contribution in double, because of my Internet connection sometimes.

I used a boolean as a result.

To build and expound on @5DN1L's advice:

GOAL:
*Please change the original alphabet example by adding << and >> at the beginning and end of this line, this will make everything in between appear as bold font.

*Please rewrite the last statement as:
"Given a classical latin [[word]], determine if this [[word]] has valid letters."

INPUT:
*Please rewrite the statement as: <<Line 1:>> A string [[word]] in classical latin.

OUTPUT:
*Please rewrite the statement as:
<<Line 1:>> If the word respects the classical latin alphabet, output {{valid}}, otherwise output {{invalid}}. 

CONSTRAINTS:
*Please move this statement to the GOAL Description, as this is not really a constraint. You can rewrite this statement as:
"The [[word]] only contains <<uppercase alphabetical>> characters."

*Please state the maximum length of [[word]]. For example:
0 < length of [[word]] < 8

BINARY-OUTPUT:
*Agree with @5DN1L on binary output issue, so please address that issue. Perhaps add a third answer to the contribution?

MODES:
*Fastest suits it, just fix the binary output and that should be ok.

VALIDATORS AND TESTS:
*Tests and their corresponding Validators should be similar but not the same. I can see a few where they have opposite answers (please see Test 4 and Validator 4, Test 5 and Validator 5). Is there some particular reason for them being like that?

CODE/SOLUTION:
*Looks good. Quite simple.

STUB GENERATOR INPUT:
*Since we already know that the longest length of [[word]] is 7, we can rewrite the first line (read-line) as:
"read word:string(7)"

I hope this is helpful for you.
Happy Coding!
Code-Parser

@Lukam90
Please note that using a boolean doesn't resolve the binary output issue. The key is to have at least three possible answers in total.

@Lukam90, following @5DN1L's statement... perhaps consider adding non-alphabetical characters to some tests and validators input [[word]]. In this way, if the [[word]] is not made up of only letters, the output should be {{UNKNOWN}}. Otherwise the same mechanics and answers apply.

I made the changes as mentionned.

I also change the problem to fix the binary output issue.

That's a very good idea. Well thought of!

Nice.

@Lukam90

Cases
* Please add a test where the word contains the letter "W".

* Please add a validator where the word contains the letter "U".

Thanks.

I added the new cases.

Thanks.

When this contribution is made public for approval, I will approve.

It looks very good now.
